title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement phgrosjean@sciviews.org. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

what: Hypothesis Tests and Statistical Distributions for SciViews::R
title: Hypothesis Tests and Statistical Distributions for SciViews::R
text: Inference Tools SciViews::R

title: Hypothesis Tests and Statistical Distributions for SciViews::R
text: {explorelit} available CRAN yet. install SciViews R-Universe. {chart} alternate formula interface {ggplot2}. {tabularise} produces publication-ready (rich-formatted) tabular output. {equatags} {equatiomatic} packages optional, useful display equations, inline R Markdown/Quarto documents {tabularise} tables. {data.io} useful manages labels units {chart} uses. install six packages dependencies, run following command R: can also install latest development version {exploreit}. Make sure {remotes} R package installed:

title: Hypothesis Tests and Statistical Distributions for SciViews::R
text: can get help package way: Make {inferit} package available R session: Get help package: instructions, please, refer help pages https://www.sciviews.org/inferit/.
code: library(inferit) library(help = "inferit") help("inferit-package") vignette("inferit") # None is installed with install_github()

title: Hypothesis Tests and Statistical Distributions for SciViews::R
text: Please note {inferit} package released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project, agree abide terms.

what: Create and plot density functions for distribution objects — dfun
title: Create and plot density functions for distribution objects — dfun
text: distribution objects represent one statistical distributions. functions dfun() geom_funfill(), together chart() allow plot .

title: Create and plot density functions for distribution objects — dfun
code: dfun(object, i = 1)  cdfun(object, i = 1)  # S3 method for distribution autoplot(   object,   n = 500,   xlim = NULL,   size = 99.5,   xlab = "Quantile",   ylab = if (type == "density") "Probability density" else     "Cumulative probability density",   plot.it = TRUE,   use.chart = FALSE,   ...,   type = "density",   theme = NULL )  # S3 method for distribution chart(data, ..., type = "density", env = parent.frame())  geom_funfill(   mapping = NULL,   data = NULL,   fun,   from,   to,   geom = "area",   fill = "salmon",   alpha = 0.5,   ... )

title: Create and plot density functions for distribution objects — dfun
text: object distribution object, distributional package. distribution use list (first one default) n number points use draw density functions (500 default) continuous distributions. xlim Two numbers limit X axis. size xlim= provided, automatically calculated using size CI 0 100 (99.5 default) continuous distributions. xlab label X axis ("Quantile" default). ylab label Y axis ("Probability density" "Cumulative probability density" default). plot.densities plotted distributions (TRUE default)? use.chart chart() used (TRUE default)? Otherwise, ggplot() used. ... arguments stat_function(). type type plot ("density" default, "cumulative"). theme theme plot (ignored now). data data frame use (NULL default). env environment use evaluate expressions. mapping mapping use (NULL default. fun function use (dfun(distribution_object)). first quantile delimit filled area. second quantile delimit filled area. geom geom use ("area" default). fill color fill area ("salmon" default). alpha alpha transparency apply, 0.5 default.

title: Create and plot density functions for distribution objects — dfun
text: Either function ggplot object.

title: Create and plot density functions for distribution objects — dfun
code: library(distributional) library(chart) #> Loading required package: ggplot2 #> Loading required package: lattice di1 <- dist_normal(mu = 1, sigma = 1.5) chart(di1) +   geom_funfill(fun = dfun(di1), from = -5, to = 1)   # With two distributions di2 <- c(dist_normal(10, 1), dist_student_t(df = 3, 13, 1)) chart(di2) +   geom_funfill(fun = dfun(di2, 1), from = -5, to = 0) +   geom_funfill(fun = dfun(di2, 2), from = 2, to = 6, fill = "turquoise3") #> Warning: no non-missing arguments to max; returning -Inf  chart$cumulative(di2)  # A discrete distribution di3 <- dist_binomial(size = 7, prob = 0.5) chart(di3)  chart$cumulative(di3)  # A continuous together with a discrete distribution di4 <- c(dist_normal(mu = 4, sigma = 2), dist_binomial(size = 8, prob = 0.5)) chart(di4)  chart$cumulative(di4)

title: Hypothesis Tests and Statistical Distributions for 'SciViews::R' — inferit-package
text: tabularise() methods htest objects. stddev() distribution objects. dfun(), cdfun() density function distribution objects. chart() method distribution objects. geom_funfill() fills part distribution density function.

what: Get standard deviation for a distribution objects — stddev
title: Get standard deviation for a distribution objects — stddev
text: distribution objects represent one statistical distributions. generic functions stddev() returns standard deviation distributions.

title: Get standard deviation for a distribution objects — stddev
code: stddev(x, ...)  # S3 method for default stddev(x, ...)  # S3 method for distribution stddev(x, ...)

title: Get standard deviation for a distribution objects — stddev
text: x distribution object, distributional package. ... arguments (used yet).

title: Get standard deviation for a distribution objects — stddev
text: numeric vector one standard deviations.

title: Get standard deviation for a distribution objects — stddev
code: library(distributional) n1 <- dist_normal(mu = 1, sigma = 1.5) n1 #> <distribution[1]> #> [1] N(1, 2.2) class(n1) #> [1] "distribution" "vctrs_vctr"   "list"         family(n1) #> [1] "normal" mean(n1) #> [1] 1 variance(n1) #> [1] 2.25 stddev(n1) #> [1] 1.5

what: Create a rich-formatted table from an htest object — tabularise_default.htest
title: Create a rich-formatted table from an htest object — tabularise_default.htest
text: tabularise() htest object (flextable) can post-edited..

title: Create a rich-formatted table from an htest object — tabularise_default.htest
code: # S3 method for htest tabularise_default(   data,   header = TRUE,   title = NULL,   lang = getOption("data.io_lang", "en"),   show.signif.stars = getOption("show.signif.stars", TRUE),   ...,   env = parent.frame() )

title: Create a rich-formatted table from an htest object — tabularise_default.htest
text: data htest object header TRUE (default), add header table title TRUE, add title table header. Default value header, except outside chunk FALSE table caption detected (tbl-cap YAML entry). lang natural language use. default value can set , e.g., options(data.io_lang = "fr") French. show.signif.stars TRUE, add significance stars table. default value obtained getOption("show.signif.stars""). ... Additional arguments (unused now). env environment evaluate lazyeval expressions (unused now).

title: Create a rich-formatted table from an htest object — tabularise_default.htest
text: flextable object can print different forms rearrange flextable functions.

title: Create a rich-formatted table from an htest object — tabularise_default.htest
text: Two sided Pearson’s product-moment correlation test Pearson’s r coefficient (CI:95%) tobs. value Df Value H0 p value  -0.1 (-0.3-0.0) -1.44 148 0 0.152  0 <= '***' < 0.001 < '**' < 0.01 < '*' < 0.05 Test t bilatéral d’indépendance à variances inégales (Welch) Différence des moyennes (IC:95%) Valeur de tobs. Ddl Valeur sous H0 Valeur de p  -8.0 (-11.1--4.9) -5.43 22 0 1.86·10-05 *** 0 <= '***' < 0.001 < '**' < 0.01 < '*' < 0.05
code: data(iris) iris_cor <- cor.test(iris$Sepal.Length, iris$Sepal.Width) tabularise::tabularise(iris_cor)
